About

THE NCCB is the Northern California Computational Biology student group for PhD, masters, and undergraduate students based in Northern California.

Students from UC Berkeley, UC Santa Cruz, UCSF, and Stanford NCCB produce a one-day symposium of student and industry talks, a poster session, and networking opportunities that encompass all fields related to computational biology.

The 2017 NCCB symposium will take place on Saturday, October 7th on Science Hill at the University of California Santa Cruz.

  • Abstract Submission

    The abstract submission deadline is August 18, 2017. Click on the bubble to submit your abstract for a 15-minute talk, a lightning talk, or a poster

  • Conference Schedule

    The conference will begin at 9AM and will end at 5PM. Click on the schedule for more information.

  • Directions

    Drive down Highway 17 or click the image to the right for more detailed instructions.

CreatureCast

CreatureCast is our series of cartoons about science. Most are made by students at Brown. This series is now distributed in partnership with the New York Times. The videos are released under a Creative Commons license, and can also be downloaded at vimeo.

Practical Computing

Steve Haddock and I wrote Practical Computing for Biologists to help biologists learn general computing skills that are relevant to many different types of data analysis.

Brown EEB

Our lab is in the Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology at Brown University.

Open Content

We produce a range of open content. This includes the code that underlies our tools and published analyses, teaching resources, essays, images, and our CreatureCast series.

Agalma

Agalma is our multifunctional phylogenetic analysis tool. We use it to build phylogenies from genome and transcriptome data, and to study the evolution of differential gene expression. The photo above is of an Agalma, the siphonophore that this tool is named after.

Siphonophores.org

Our site about siphonophores.
